material_source_passage: Traditional silicon-based devices could not show desirable NIR photoresponse due to limitation of opticalbandgap (1.12 eV) of silicon [1], and many attempts have been made to enhance the absorptance of silicon material, especially at NIR wavelengths [2-9]. The discovery of chalcogen-super saturated silicon fabricated by laser irradiation in SF<sub>6</sub> atmosphere demonstrated an approach to enhance the sub-bandgap absorption [10, 11]. In this process, the material can be doped beyond the solubility limit [12]. Besides, light trapping effect caused by the unique pointed cone structure on silicon surface also in-creases the efficiency of light absorption [13].
property_source_passage: Traditional silicon-based devices could not show desirable NIR photoresponse due to limitation of opticalbandgap (1.12 eV) of silicon [1], and many attempts have been made to enhance the absorptance of silicon material, especially at NIR wavelengths [2-9]. The discovery of chalcogen-super saturated silicon fabricated by laser irradiation in SF6 atmosphere demonstrated an approach to enhance the sub-bandgap absorption [10, 11]. In this process, the material can be doped beyond the solubility limit [12]. Besides, light trapping effect caused by the unique pointed cone structure on silicon surface also in-creases the efficiency of light absorption [13].
value_source_passage: Traditional silicon-based devices could not show desirable NIR photoresponse due to limitation of opticalbandgap (1.12 eV) of silicon [1], and many attempts have been made to enhance the absorptance of silicon material, especially at NIR wavelengths [2-9]. The discovery of chalcogen-super saturated silicon fabricated by laser irradiation in SF6 atmosphere demonstrated an approach to enhance the sub-bandgap absorption [10, 11]. In this process, the material can be doped beyond the solubility limit [12]. Besides, light trapping effect caused by the unique pointed cone structure on silicon surface also in-creases the efficiency of light absorption [13].

material_descriptor:
Sulfur-Hyperdoped
N+/P Photodiodes
Ion-implantated at room temperature
Ion-implanted with 1.2 keV <sup>32</sup>S<sup>+</sup>
Ion-implantated depth of approximately 40 nm
Pulsed laser melting
Annealed at 650 °C
material_source_passage: The observed photoresponse in NIR is ascribed to the sulfur impurity levels in hyperdoped silicon. Such impur-ity levels facilitate the below bandgap absorption asmentioned above. The absorbed NIR light is convertedinto electron-hole pairs, resulting in the enhancement ofphotoresponse in NIR range (1100 ~ 1600 nm) [20]. Thedevice with implantation dose of 10<sup>14</sup> ions/cm<sup>2</sup> showsthe highest photoresponse in the wavelength range of1010-1100 nm. The broad peak has been investigatedowning to deep sulfur levels in femtosecond laser-processed silicon [20, 26]. In addition, we found that the device with 10 14 ions/cm 2 has showed higher photoresponse than those with 10<sup>15</sup> and 10<sup>16</sup> ions/cm<sup>2</sup>. And the Hall measurement indicated that the sample implanted at 10 14 ions/cm 2 had a bulk concentration of 10<sup>19</sup> ions/cm<sup>3</sup>.
property_descriptor:
van der Pauw technique
room temperature

material_descriptor:
p-type
wafers
ion-implanted with 1.2 keV <sup>32</sup>S<sup>+</sup>
ion-implanted depth of approximately 40 nm at room temperature
material_source_passage: One-side polished p-type silicon [100] wafers (300 μm) with resistivity 8-12 Ω cm were ion-implanted with 1.2 keV <sup>32</sup>S<sup>+</sup> into a depth of approximately 40 nm at room temperature. The implantation doses were 1× 10<sup>14</sup>,1×10<sup>15</sup>, and 1×10<sup>16</sup> ions/cm<sup>2</sup>. Pulsed laser melt-ing (PLM) was carried out by 1 kHz train of 100 fs,800 nm femtosecond laser pulses with a fluence of 0.5 J/cm<sup>2</sup>. Then, laser spot of 200 μm diameter is focused on the silicon and patterned square areas up to10 mm×10 mm. Rapid thermal annealing (RTA) wasimplemented at 600 °C for 30 min in a N<sub>2</sub> atmosphere.
property_source_passage: One-side polished p-type silicon [100] wafers (300 μm) with resistivity 8-12 Ω cm were ion-implanted with 1.2 keV <sup>32</sup>S<sup>+</sup> into a depth of approximately 40 nm at room temperature. The implantation doses were 1× 10<sup>14</sup>,1×10<sup>15</sup>, and 1×10<sup>16</sup> ions/cm<sup>2</sup>. Pulsed laser melt-ing (PLM) was carried out by 1 kHz train of 100 fs,800 nm femtosecond laser pulses with a fluence of0.5 J/cm<sup>2</sup>. Then, laser spot of 200 μmdiameterisfo-cused on the silicon and patterned square areas up to10 mm×10 mm. Rapid thermal annealing (RTA) wasimplemented at 600 °C for 30 min in a N<sub>2</sub> atmosphere.

The implantation doses were 1× 10<sup>14</sup>,1×10<sup>15</sup>, and 1×10<sup>16</sup> ions/cm<sup>2</sup>. Pulsed laser melt-ing (PLM) was carried out by 1 kHz train of 100 fs,800 nm femtosecond laser pulses with a fluence of0.5 J/cm<sup>2</sup>. Then, laser spot of 200 μmdiameterisfo-cused on the silicon and patterned square areas up to10 mm×10 mm. Rapid thermal annealing (RTA) wasimplemented at 600 °C for 30 min in a N<sub>2</sub> atmosphere.
